topic.title: Device Interface

body.p: For the AC timing characteristics of this interface, see Device Interface.

entry.p: The nominal 155.52 or 125 MHz reference clock is used as a reference for all High Speed SERDES when operating at their nominal rates. It is also used as a reference for the internal data paths. External holdover circuitry is required to ensure glitch free transition between sources.
Microsemi recommends use of the Microsemi ZLE30169 device for the REFCLK input jitter attenuator (JAT).
LVDS compatible differential input with internal 100 â„¦ termination. External AC coupling capacitors are required.

p.b: PCIe, SGMII, XFI and CPU Clock

entry.p: Clock used for all control plane functions such as the PCIe interface, SGMII interfaces, XFI Interfaces and the CPU.
Differential LVDS inputs. The PCIE_REFCLK_P/N input requires an external 100 â„¦ differential termination.

The device reset is an asynchronous active low reset. While reset is active, all serial receive interfaces are powered down and all serial transmit interfaces are squelched. RSTB resets all registers to their default value.

p.b: Tristate and pad pull up / pull down disable Control

entry.p: Driving the HIZ input high puts all LVCMOS and LVDS outputs in a high impedance state for latch-up testing and disables all pull up/down resistors on all LVCMOS pads for improved LVCMOS pad leakage testing.
HIZ should be tied low for normal operation.

INTB asserts low whenever an unmasked interrupt event is detected on any of the internal interrupt sources. Each major interrupt output from a major subsystem block can be independently unmasked to drive INTB and/or the PCIe interface interrupt (MSI/MSIX). Note that INTB remains low until all active unmasked interrupt sources are acknowledged at their source. At this time, INTB becomes high-impedance.
An external pull-up resistor of 1 to 10 kâ„¦ is required on the pin to pull the line up to logic 1 when INTB is deasserted.
The PGMRCLK[7:0] outputs are configurable to provide access to all of the client recovered / transmit clocks and DCSU outputs within the device.

A fractional divider is provided on all of the PGMRCLK outputs. Each output supports 125 MHz maximum. The division ratio for each fractional divider is register configurable using an 8-bit integer, 32-bit numerator, and 32-bit denominator.
See Programmable Recovered Clocks (PGMRCLK) for more information.
The PLL_STATUS[0] output provides direct access to a divided-down version of the 100 MHz device PCIE_REFCLK. This clock is divided down by a factor of 256 to 390.6 kHz.
The PLL_STATUS[1] output provides direct access to a divided-down version of the 200 MHz device configuration bus clock (PCLK). This clock is divided down by a factor of 256 to 781.25 kHz.

The PLL_STATUS[1:0] outputs will not begin toggling until loading and execution of the boot code from the external SPI flash device has been completed by device firmware. Toggling of the outputs can be used by an external device to detect when loading and execution of the boot loader code is complete. Before toggling they will drive low.
See Programmable Recovered Clocks (PGMRCLK) for more information.

This device contains several periodic pulse generators that can be used to initiate periodic reads of performance monitoring counters in the device. These generators can be synchronized externally by providing a rising edge on PMON_SYNC_I.
AC timing is provided in PMON_SYNC_I.
1.8 V LVCMOS18 low-speed signal with pull down.
PMON_SYNC_O can be used to drive the PMON_SYNC_I of other devices. It can be configured to output a periodic pulse at a user-programmable interval.
AC timing is provided in PMON_SYNC_O.

p.b: 8 kHz SAR Delay Compensation Timing Reference

entry.p: The 8 kHz Delay Compensation Timing Reference is used to synchronize SAR packet header timestamps carried by data transmitted across the backplane fabric or the ODUk switch. These timestamps are used to compensate for packet delay variation across a fabric and to maintain fabric buffers at a desired fill level. Additionally, these timestamps are used to track the ODUflex resizing ramp by tracking to maintain a constant fabric latency during a resizing ramp event.

The FPI 8 kHz frame pulse is required for all applications in which ODUk packets are sent over the Interlaken interface. The frame pulse is not required when the Interlaken interface is not used and ODUk packets do not exit the device. Internal logic will flywheel when the frame pulse is not present. The frame pulse period can be an integer multiple of 125 us (for example 2 kHz). FPI must maintain a fixed phase relationship with REFCLK_P/N.

p.ph: See FPI Reshaping for more information.

entry.p: 1.8 V LVCMOS18 low-speed signal; active high pulse.

The TX_MFPI input may be used to synchronize the transmit OTU4 or OTUCn frame alignments of the device. TX_MFPI is intended to be driven by one of the 8 PGMRCLK outputs from a master device that has been configured to output the multiframe pulse from a transmit OTU4 or OTUCn signal from one of the six OTU4 for LINEOTN.

Please refer to PREP #336466 which describes one possible application of the otn_tx_mfpi input. Also, refer to the MFP Offset description in DIGI G5 M1 Engineering Document (PDOX 422659), which shows the logic driven by otn_tx_mfpi inside the device.
1.8 V LVCMOS18 low-speed signal; active high pulse.
When SERDES_LOS[x] is set to 1, the corresponding receive datapath performs protocol-specific consequential actions.
Each SERDES_LOS[x] can be switched to any lane of the LINEOTN, SYSTON, and ENET subsystems. LOS switching is configured independently of Line Receive Data switching.
Each SERDES_LOS[x] can be independently inverted and disabled.
Reference clock for optical modules. OM_REFCLK[11:0] is a nominally 50% duty cycle clock with frequency 1/1024 of the transmit data rate.
Microsemi recommends use of the Microsemi ZLE30169 or ZLE30182 (dual variant of the ZLE30169) as the jitter attenuator (JAT) and clock multiplier for the OM_REFCLK outputs.
Refer to the hardware design guide for recommended connection.

p.b: Bootstrap for ARM invasive debug enable

entry.p: 0: Invasive debug disabled at boot (can be overridden later using CPU_ICP PCBI NREGS fields).
1: Secure invasive debug permitted at boot (can be overridden later using CPU_ICP PCBI NREGS fields). Enabling invasive debug implies non-invasive debug is also permitted.
Refer to the hardware design guide for recommended connection.

p.b: Bootstrap for ARM non-invasive debug enable

entry.p: This input is only relevant when BOOTSTRAP_DBGEN=0 to disable invasive debug at boot.
0: Non-invasive debug disabled at boot (can be overridden later using CPU_ICP PCBI NREGS fields)
1: Secure non-invasive debug permitted at boot (can be overridden later using CPU_ICP PCBI NREGS fields)
Refer to the hardware design guide for recommended connection.

p.b: Bootstrap to select SPI Quad/Single mode at boot

entry.p: 1: Quad SPI mode, with Quad SPI mode specifics controlled by BOOTSTRAP[1:0]
Refer to the hardware design guide for recommended connection.

p.b: Bootstrap to select SPI ECC on/off at boot

entry.p: 0: Inline ECC is disabled on boot device at boot-up
1: Inline ECC is enabled on boot device at boot-up
Refer to the hardware design guide for recommended connection.

p.b: Bootstrap to select SPI soft reset sequence on/off

entry.p: 1: Enables executing soft reset sequence to bring flash to default state once SPI controller comes out of reset
Refer to the hardware design guide for recommended connection.

p.b: Bootstrap to select the specific Quad SPI mode in use when BOOTSTRAP_MSPI_MODE_SEL=1

entry.p: 00: Quad Output Read (QOR) (1-1-4) CMD=0x6B, 8 dummy cycles
01: Quad Input-Output Read (QIOR) (1-4-4) CMD=0xEB, 6 dummy cycles
10: Quad Input-Output Read (QIOR) (1-4-4) CMD=0xEB, 8 dummy cycles
11: Quad Input-Output Read (QIOR) (1-4-4) CMD=0xEB, 10 dummy cycles
Please refer to PREPID 440494 for discussion related to this setting.
Refer to the hardware design guide for recommended connection.

b.b: Test Point Receive Input - UART Serial Data Input

entry.p: UART Data input from the modem or peripheral device.
Test point input. Refer to the hardware design guide for recommended connection.

b.b: Test Point Transmit Output - UART Serial Data Output

entry.p: UART Data output to the modem or peripheral device.
Test point output. Refer to the hardware design guide for recommended connection.
